titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Stanley Braithwaite Papers
titlestmt.author: by H. Dean and Olivia Coates

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:46

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The William Stanley Braithwaite Papers document his personal and professional life and span the dates 1797 to 1942. The Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers, which provide evidence of Braithwaite's career as a writer, publisher, and anthologist. The Papers also includes third-party correspondence, notably, a letter from Sir Joseph Banks to J. Nicol from circa 1797.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Walter R. Benjamin and Margaret Carpenter on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2003 and from William Reese Company on the Danford N. Barney, Jr. Fund, 1991.
The addition was purchased from Southpaw Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.
Other material came to the library in small quantities from various sources as indicated on individual folders.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Part of the William Stanley Braithwaite Papers are derived from JWJ MSS Small Collections. A list for JWJ MSS Small Collections was created in the 1980s by graduate students who conducted a survey of collections under the direction of the curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature. The Beinecke Library received additional Braithwaite material after this list was created. In 2010 the Papers received further processing, at which time JWJ MSS Small Collections Braithwaite was interfiled with Za Braithwaite, Uncat.JWJ MS.47, and JWJ Zan B731 +1.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William Stanley Braithwaite Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Stanley Braithwaite Papers. James Weldon Johnson Collection in the Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are microfilmed, as noted on individual folders.

bioghist.head: William Stanley Beaumont Braithwaite (1878-1962)
bioghist.p: William Stanley Braithwaite was born in Boston, December 6, 1878, to William Smith Braithwaite and Emma DeWolf. He led a difficult life as a child of two mixed race parents and due to the death of his father in 1886, he left school early and joined the workforce at the age of twelve. His first employment was fortuitous; he was apprenticed in a Boston publishing house where he was exposed to the works of John Keats. Braithwaite acquired a passion for romantic poetry which drew him to a literary life. In 1903 he married Emma Kelly with whom he had seven children. Following his marriage, he committed himself even more intensely to his literary career, and completed and published his first volume of poetry, Lyrics of Life and Love (1904). He traveled to New York City in search of a career in journalism, but encountered an unfamiliar atmosphere of racial prejudice and soon returned to Boston where he found employment in 1906 as a critic and reviewer for The Boston Evening Transcript . While at The Transcript he published his first anthologies as collections of the year's best poetry. In 1908 he completed his best-known work of poetry, The House of Falling Leaves , in which he explored the development of African-American writing in the U.S. He attempted to start up his own literary publication, The Poetic Journal and a publishing house, B.J. Brimmer, which he founded with fellow poet Winifred Virginia Jackson. Both ventures proved unsuccessful and Braithwaite was beset with financial difficulties. In 1935, after having received several honorary degrees he was offered a professorship at Atlanta University which he held until 1945. Braithwaite returned to New York City and completed his final collection of poems, Selected Poems , in 1948 and remained there until his death on June 8, 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Stanley Braithwaite Papers document his personal and professional life and span the dates 1797 to 1942. The Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers, which provide evidence of Braithwaite's career as a writer, publisher, and anthologist.

Braithwaite's correspondence records his professional and, to a lesser degree, personal relationships. Correspondents include poets such as Stephen Vincent Benét, William Rose Benét, Witter Bynner, Sarah Norcliffe Cleghorn, Grace Hazard Conkling, Olive Tilford Dargan, Rebecca Harding Davis, John Gould Fletcher, Georgia Douglas Johnson, James Weldon Johnson, James Joyce, Joyce Kilmer, Aline Murray Kilmer, Vachel Lindsay, Philip Ainsworth Means, and Louis Untermeyer. Other correspondents include W.E.B. DuBois and George E. Haynes. The correspondence series also contains third-party correspondence; notably, a letter from Sir Joseph Banks to J. Nicol from circa1797.

Proofs, clippings of articles, and publicity materials represent Braithwaite's career as an anthologist and as an author for The Boston Evening Transcript . Other papers document his work as a publisher (with B.J. Brimmer) and lecturer. The papers also contain a portrait and a photograph of Braithwaite as well as his collection of autographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, circa 1797, 1877-1942. II. Writings, 1908-1928. III. Other Papers, 1830-1935, undated. IV. Addition, 1911-1935.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two subseries: William Stanley Braithwaite Correspondence and Third-Party Correspondence. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence dating from 1797 to 1942 documenting Braithwaite's career. The correspondence provides insight into Braithwaite's relationships with authors and pertains to his work as a critic and anthologist. There are numerous letters between Braithwaite and authors regarding his anthologies. In their letters correspondents often grant permission to Braithwaite to include their pieces in his anthologies and some authors enclose copies of their poems and details regarding last minute changes to their writing (such as edits to a particular poem and justifications for such changes). Braithwaite also corresponded extensively with Arthur Upson's mother Mrs. Julia Upson and fiancée Ruth Shepard Phelps following Upson's death in 1908. Correspondents include: Stephen Vincent Benét, William Rose Benét, Witter Bynner, Sarah Norcliffe Cleghorn, Grace Hazard Conkling, Olive Tilford Dargan, Rebecca Harding Davis, William E. B. DuBois, John Gould Fletcher, George E. Haynes, Georgia Douglas Johnson, James Weldon Johnson, James Joyce, Joyce and Aline Murray Kilmer, Vachel Lindsay, Philip Ainsworth Means, and Louis Untermeyer.

The series also includes third-party correspondence such as a letter from Sir Joseph Banks to J. Nicol and correspondence between Frederick A. Kent and various government officials. Braithwaite's correspondence with Rebecca Harding Davis includes correspondence with Mary Allen and other third-parties. Braithwaite collected autographs so it is possible that some of the third-party correspondence reflects this pursuit. Braithwaite's autograph collection is in Series III.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence from Samuel W. McCall, Henry E. Burnham, Jacob H. Gallinger, and other government officials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains extensive publicity material for Braithwaite's writing projects, both as an anthologist and a journalist. Braithwaite's career with the The Boston Evening Transcript is reflected in the various clippings of his writings (loose and as part of a scrapbook) from the newspaper dating from 1916 to 1924. The series also includes page proofs for The Book of Victorian Verse and a handwritten list of permissions for an anthology.

List of permissions for an anthology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other Papers contains material that provides evidence of Braithwaite's career as a publisher, with the B.J. Brimmer Company, and as a lecturer. The series also includes Braithwaite's autograph collection, a portrait, and a photograph of Braithwaite.

did.unittitle: "Braithwaite's Course on the Theory and Practice of Verse," publicity material

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Southpaw Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015. Vendor lis is filed at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The addition contains correspondence, writings, and printed material relating to William Stanley Braithwaite.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns Boie's request for Braithwaite to send a letter to Mrs. Edward McDowell of the McDowell Colony on behalf of Boie. Enclosed is a typescript draft short story by Boie, entitled "Cold Countries", clippings of writings by Boie, and Braithwaite's draft to McDowell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes typescript and typescript carbon drafts of opinions by others on Davis's Lovers Of Life: An Epic Biography Of A Soul.

scopecontent.p: Braithwaite was president of the company
